post.title: Scalding Hot Coffee
post.content:
For once, we have some science in this first-world insanity.

It goes like this. . .
You drink some scalding hot coffee, and you burn the roof of your mouth
and traumatize your poor tongue. Next, you're spitting dead skin for the whole morning.

Problem: "Oh DEAR GOD, my coffee scalded my tongue! It's too hot!"



Solution: Ever heard of cold milk? 
Probably not. The lack of milk can also be a first-world problem. . . 

Anyway - Here comes science to the rescue!

Say you only have a metal spoon.
By stirring the coffee, you're giving it a larger surface area to make contact with the air. 
The problem with this is it also heats the coffee as a result of the joule effect.
Metal is also a good conductor, you could just LEAVE the spoon in the coffee.
Of course, the spoon will get hot. . . .
So the best method is to dip a metal spoon in and out of a coffee.

There's that and cold milk. Seriously, a trip to the supermarket will not kill you.
